metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The change in position of equilibrium that can occur when changes in temperature or species or volume (concentration or pressure) are applied to a system at equilibrium, and the representation of these changes using concentration-time graphs

le_chatelier_principle.name: Le Chatelier's Principle
le_chatelier_principle.formula: System opposes change to restore equilibrium
le_chatelier_principle.correct: When an equilibrium system is subjected to a change, the system adjusts to partially oppose that change and restore equilibrium.

completely reverses the change.error: The system PARTIALLY opposes, not completely reverses.
completely reverses the change.fix: Le Chatelier's says the system adjusts to PARTIALLY oppose the change. Some effect remains.
completely reverses the change.action: If you add reactant, the system uses some but not all of it. New equilibrium has higher concentration than before.

amplifies the change.error: That's the opposite of what happens.
amplifies the change.fix: The system works AGAINST the change, not with it. Opposition, not amplification.
amplifies the change.action: Think: system tries to return toward original state, not move further away.

has no effect.error: Equilibrium systems definitely respond to changes.
has no effect.fix: Le Chatelier's principle exists because systems DO respond to disturbances.
has no effect.action: Try adding acid to a buffer - the pH changes, just not as much as expected.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how equilibrium systems respond to stress.
persistent.action: For each change, ask: what would oppose this? Then predict the shift direction.

adding_reactant.name: Effect of Adding Reactant
adding_reactant.formula: Add reactant ‚Üí forward reaction favoured ‚Üí shift right
adding_reactant.correct: Adding reactant increases its concentration, so the system opposes this by consuming reactant via the forward reaction, shifting equilibrium to the right.

shifts left.error: Opposite direction. Adding reactant favours the forward reaction.
shifts left.fix: To reduce excess reactant, the system must USE it - that's the forward reaction.
shifts left.action: Add N‚ÇÇ to N‚ÇÇ + 3H‚ÇÇ ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ. System makes more NH‚ÇÉ to use up the extra N‚ÇÇ.

increases product concentration only.error: Product increases, but so does the other reactant (temporarily) before new equilibrium.
increases product concentration only.fix: The shift to products consumes BOTH reactants, but overall products increase more.
increases product concentration only.action: Both sides change. The NET effect favours products, but all concentrations adjust.

no change occurs.error: Adding species to an equilibrium definitely causes a response.
no change occurs.fix: Any concentration change disturbs equilibrium. The system MUST adjust.
no change occurs.action: The system was balanced. Adding more of one species unbalances it.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting concentration changes to reaction direction.
persistent.action: Practice: for A + B ‚áå C, what happens when you add A? Add B? Add C?

adding_product.name: Effect of Adding Product
adding_product.formula: Add product ‚Üí reverse reaction favoured ‚Üí shift left
adding_product.correct: Adding product increases its concentration, so the system opposes this by consuming product via the reverse reaction, shifting equilibrium to the left.

shifts right.error: Wrong direction. Adding product favours the REVERSE reaction.
shifts right.fix: To reduce excess product, the system must convert product back to reactants.
shifts right.action: Add NH‚ÇÉ to N‚ÇÇ + 3H‚ÇÇ ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ. System breaks down NH‚ÇÉ, making more N‚ÇÇ and H‚ÇÇ.

forward reaction speeds up.error: Confusing rate with position. More product favours the reverse direction.
forward reaction speeds up.fix: Adding product increases collisions for reverse reaction more than forward.
forward reaction speeds up.action: Position shifts left even though forward reaction still occurs.

K increases.error: K doesn't change with concentration changes.
K increases.fix: Only TEMPERATURE changes K. Adding or removing species changes position, not K.
K increases.action: K is the ratio at equilibrium. The system adjusts concentrations to maintain K.

persistent.gap: You're confusing equilibrium position with equilibrium constant.
persistent.action: Remember: concentration changes affect POSITION. Temperature changes affect K.

removing_species.name: Effect of Removing Species
removing_species.formula: Remove species ‚Üí reaction produces more of it
removing_species.correct: Removing a species decreases its concentration, so the system opposes this by producing more of that species.

system produces less of it.error: That would amplify the change, not oppose it.
system produces less of it.fix: Le Chatelier's says OPPOSE. If you remove something, the system makes more.
system produces less of it.action: Remove product ‚Üí system makes more product (shifts right).

equilibrium cannot be re-established.error: The system will find a new equilibrium position.
equilibrium cannot be re-established.fix: Removing species is just the opposite of adding. A new equilibrium forms.
equilibrium cannot be re-established.action: Industrial processes use this: remove product continuously to drive reaction forward.

K decreases.error: K is unchanged by concentration changes.
K decreases.fix: Removing species changes position to MAINTAIN K, not change it.
K decreases.action: The ratio of products to reactants (K) stays the same at the new equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You don't understand that removal is just the opposite of addition.
persistent.action: Practice: removing product shifts right (makes more product). Removing reactant shifts left.

temperature_exothermic.name: Temperature Effect on Exothermic Reactions
temperature_exothermic.formula: Increase T ‚Üí reverse favoured, K decreases
temperature_exothermic.correct: For exothermic reactions, increasing temperature favours the reverse (endothermic) direction because the system absorbs heat to oppose the change. K decreases.

forward reaction favoured.error: Opposite. Exothermic reactions are opposed by high temperature.
forward reaction favoured.fix: High T means excess heat. System uses heat by running the endothermic (reverse) direction.
forward reaction favoured.action: Write heat as a product: A + B ‚áå C + heat. More heat shifts LEFT.

K stays the same.error: Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes K.
K stays the same.fix: Temperature changes the actual equilibrium constant value, not just the position.
K stays the same.action: Look up K values for NH‚ÇÉ synthesis at different temperatures - they're different.

K increases.error: K decreases for exothermic reactions when T increases.
K increases.fix: Higher T, less product at equilibrium ‚Üí smaller ratio ‚Üí smaller K.
K increases.action: K = [products]/[reactants]. Less product means smaller K.

persistent.gap: You're not treating heat as a 'product' in exothermic reactions.
persistent.action: Always write the enthalpy. If ŒîH < 0, heat is a product. Adding heat shifts left.

temperature_endothermic.name: Temperature Effect on Endothermic Reactions
temperature_endothermic.formula: Increase T ‚Üí forward favoured, K increases
temperature_endothermic.correct: For endothermic reactions, increasing temperature favours the forward direction because the system absorbs heat to oppose the change. K increases.

reverse reaction favoured.error: Opposite. Endothermic reactions are favoured by high temperature.
reverse reaction favoured.fix: High T means excess heat. Endothermic reactions USE heat, so they're favoured.
reverse reaction favoured.action: Write heat as a reactant: heat + A ‚áå B. More heat shifts RIGHT.

K stays the same.error: Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes K.
K stays the same.fix: For endothermic reactions, higher T means larger K (more products at equilibrium).
K stays the same.action: This is why some reactions only work at high temperatures - K is too small at low T.

K decreases.error: K increases for endothermic reactions when T increases.
K decreases.fix: Higher T, more product at equilibrium ‚Üí larger ratio ‚Üí larger K.
K decreases.action: Endothermic absorbs heat. More heat available ‚Üí more product ‚Üí larger K.

persistent.gap: You're not treating heat as a 'reactant' in endothermic reactions.
persistent.action: Always write the enthalpy. If ŒîH > 0, heat is a reactant. Adding heat shifts right.

pressure_increase.name: Effect of Increasing Pressure
pressure_increase.formula: Increase P ‚Üí favours side with fewer moles of gas
pressure_increase.correct: Increasing pressure favours the reaction that produces fewer moles of gas, because this reduces the total number of gas particles and opposes the pressure increase.

favours more moles.error: That would INCREASE pressure further, not oppose it.
favours more moles.fix: To reduce pressure, reduce the number of particles. Favour fewer moles.
favours more moles.action: N‚ÇÇ + 3H‚ÇÇ ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ has 4 moles left, 2 right. High P shifts right.

no effect on equilibrium.error: Pressure affects gas equilibria when moles differ on each side.
no effect on equilibrium.fix: If reactant moles ‚â† product moles, pressure DOES affect equilibrium position.
no effect on equilibrium.action: Count moles on each side. If different, pressure matters.

K changes.fix: Only temperature changes K. Pressure changes position to maintain K.
K changes.action: The ratio K stays the same; concentrations adjust to keep it constant.

persistent.gap: You're not counting gas moles to predict pressure effects.
persistent.action: For every equilibrium, count gas moles on each side. The side with fewer is favoured at high P.

pressure_decrease.name: Effect of Decreasing Pressure
pressure_decrease.formula: Decrease P ‚Üí favours side with more moles of gas
pressure_decrease.correct: Decreasing pressure favours the reaction that produces more moles of gas, because this increases the total number of gas particles and opposes the pressure decrease.

favours fewer moles.error: That would decrease pressure further, not oppose it.
favours fewer moles.fix: To increase pressure back up, make more particles. Favour more moles.
favours fewer moles.action: N‚ÇÇ + 3H‚ÇÇ ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ: low P shifts left (toward 4 moles, not 2).

same as increasing pressure.error: Opposite effects. Low P favours the opposite side to high P.
same as increasing pressure.fix: Low P ‚Üí more moles favoured. High P ‚Üí fewer moles favoured.
same as increasing pressure.action: Think of it as: system tries to fill the extra space (low P) or reduce crowding (high P).

volume change has no effect.error: Volume and pressure are inversely related. They have opposite effects.
volume change has no effect.fix: Decrease volume = increase pressure. Increase volume = decrease pressure.
volume change has no effect.action: Halving volume doubles pressure. The effects are linked but opposite.

persistent.gap: You're confusing pressure and volume effects.
persistent.action: Remember: low P (or high V) favours MORE moles. High P (or low V) favours FEWER moles.

inert_gas_addition.name: Effect of Adding Inert Gas
inert_gas_addition.formula: Inert gas at constant V ‚Üí no effect on equilibrium
inert_gas_addition.correct: Adding an inert gas at constant volume increases total pressure but doesn't change the partial pressures of reactants or products, so equilibrium position is unchanged.

shifts toward fewer moles.error: That would happen if PARTIAL pressures increased, but they don't.
shifts toward fewer moles.fix: Inert gas doesn't participate. The reacting gases' partial pressures are unchanged.
shifts toward fewer moles.action: Only the partial pressures of N‚ÇÇ, H‚ÇÇ, NH‚ÇÉ matter, not the total pressure.

shifts toward more moles.error: No shift occurs because partial pressures are unchanged.
shifts toward more moles.fix: Adding He to the system doesn't change [N‚ÇÇ] or [H‚ÇÇ] or [NH‚ÇÉ].
shifts toward more moles.action: The equilibrium expression doesn't include inert gas concentration.

K changes.error: Inert gas doesn't affect K or equilibrium position.
K changes.fix: K only depends on temperature. Inert gas affects neither K nor position.
K changes.action: The inert gas is irrelevant to the equilibrium calculation.

persistent.gap: You're confusing total pressure with partial pressures.
persistent.action: Learn: at constant V, inert gas increases total P but not partial P of reacting species.

graph_interpretation.name: Concentration-Time Graph Interpretation
graph_interpretation.correct: On a concentration-time graph, a disturbance appears as a sudden change followed by gradual adjustment to new constant concentrations at the new equilibrium.

concentrations return to original values.error: They reach NEW equilibrium values, not the original ones.
concentrations return to original values.fix: The system partially opposes the change. New equilibrium ‚â† old equilibrium.
concentrations return to original values.action: If you add reactant, final [reactant] is higher than before adding (but lower than just after adding).

only one concentration changes.error: All species in the equilibrium adjust their concentrations.
only one concentration changes.fix: When equilibrium shifts, ALL concentrations change to reach the new balance.
only one concentration changes.action: If forward is favoured, products increase AND reactants decrease.

concentrations change linearly.error: The change is curved, approaching a plateau asymptotically.
concentrations change linearly.fix: Rate of change slows as equilibrium is approached. Curve flattens.
concentrations change linearly.action: Look for the characteristic curve: fast initial change, then gradual levelling off.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how equilibrium graphs show disturbances and re-establishment.
persistent.action: Sketch 5 graphs: add reactant, add product, remove product, increase T (exo), increase P.

catalyst_effect.name: Effect of Catalyst on Equilibrium
catalyst_effect.correct: A catalyst speeds up both forward and reverse reactions equally, so equilibrium is reached faster but the equilibrium position and K are unchanged.

shifts equilibrium right.error: Catalysts don't favour one direction over the other.
shifts equilibrium right.fix: Catalysts lower activation energy for BOTH directions equally.
shifts equilibrium right.action: The ratio of forward to reverse rate stays the same - just both are faster.

increases K.fix: K depends only on temperature. Catalysts affect rate, not thermodynamics.
increases K.action: The final equilibrium position is identical with or without catalyst.

changes yield of products.error: Yield at equilibrium is unchanged by catalyst.
changes yield of products.fix: You get to the same equilibrium faster, but the equilibrium itself is unchanged.
changes yield of products.action: Catalyst helps you reach equilibrium quickly but doesn't change where equilibrium lies.

persistent.action: Catalysts are kinetic - they affect speed. K and position are thermodynamic - unchanged by catalyst.

concentration_changes.title: Effect of Concentration Changes
concentration_changes.instructions: Complete the statements about how changes in concentration affect equilibrium position.

sentences.text: Le Chatelier's principle states that when an equilibrium system is disturbed, it will adjust to {{d1}} the change and {{d2}} equilibrium.

d1.tooltip: The system fights back, but not completely.

sentences.text: When a reactant is added to a system at equilibrium, the concentration of that reactant {{d3}}, causing the {{d4}} reaction to be favoured.

d4.tooltip: Which reaction uses up the excess reactant?

sentences.text: When a product is added to a system at equilibrium, the equilibrium position shifts to the {{d5}}, meaning the {{d6}} reaction is favoured.

d5.tooltip: The system opposes by making less product.

d6.tooltip: Which reaction uses up the excess product?

sentences.text: Removing a product from an equilibrium system causes the equilibrium to shift {{d7}}, as the system tries to {{d8}} the removed species.

d7.tooltip: Shift in the direction that makes more product.

temperature_changes.title: Effect of Temperature Changes
temperature_changes.instructions: Complete the statements about how temperature changes affect equilibrium position and K.

sentences.text: Temperature is unique among factors because it is the only one that changes the value of the {{d1}} as well as the equilibrium {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: K is only affected by one variable.

sentences.text: For an exothermic reaction where ŒîH is {{d3}}, increasing the temperature will favour the {{d4}} reaction.

d4.tooltip: The endothermic direction absorbs the extra heat.

sentences.text: When temperature increases for an exothermic reaction, the equilibrium constant K will {{d5}} because there will be relatively {{d6}} product at equilibrium.

d5.tooltip: Less product means a smaller ratio.

sentences.text: For an endothermic reaction, increasing the temperature favours the {{d7}} reaction, causing K to {{d8}}.

d8.tooltip: More product means a larger ratio.

pressure_volume.title: Effect of Pressure and Volume Changes
pressure_volume.instructions: Complete the statements about how pressure and volume changes affect gaseous equilibria.

sentences.text: When the pressure of a gaseous equilibrium system is increased, the equilibrium shifts toward the side with {{d1}} moles of gas.
For the reaction N‚ÇÇ(g) + 3H‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ(g), increasing the pressure will shift the equilibrium to the {{d2}} because there are {{d3}} moles of gas on the product side.

d2.tooltip: 4 moles on left, 2 moles on right.

sentences.text: Decreasing the volume of a container is equivalent to {{d4}} the pressure, which favours the side with {{d5}} moles of gas.

d4.tooltip: Same gas, smaller space = higher pressure.

d5.tooltip: System opposes by reducing particle count.

sentences.text: Adding an inert gas at constant volume {{d6}} the position of equilibrium because the {{d7}} of the reacting gases are unchanged.

d6.tooltip: Inert gas doesn't participate in the reaction.

d7.tooltip: Only partial pressures of reactants and products matter.

graphs.title: Concentration-Time Graphs
graphs.instructions: Complete the statements about interpreting concentration-time graphs for equilibrium systems.

sentences.text: At equilibrium, a concentration-time graph shows {{d1}} lines for all species, indicating that concentrations are {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: No change over time = flat line.

d2.tooltip: Dynamic equilibrium: constant but not necessarily equal concentrations.

sentences.text: When a disturbance occurs, the concentration-time graph shows a {{d3}} change followed by a gradual adjustment to {{d4}} constant values.

d3.tooltip: The disturbance is an instantaneous event.

d4.tooltip: A new equilibrium, not the same as before.

sentences.text: Adding a catalyst to an equilibrium system causes equilibrium to be reached {{d5}}, but the final concentrations at equilibrium are {{d6}}.
On a concentration-time graph, when the forward reaction is favoured, product concentrations {{d7}} while reactant concentrations {{d8}} until new equilibrium is reached.

d8.tooltip: Reactants are consumed by the forward reaction.

concentration_changes.title: Applying Concentration Change Principles
concentration_changes.instructions: Apply Le Chatelier's principle to predict outcomes of concentration changes.

sentences.text: In the Haber process, N‚ÇÇ(g) + 3H‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ(g), if nitrogen is continuously added, the yield of ammonia will {{d1}} as the equilibrium {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Adding reactant drives the forward reaction.

sentences.text: Industrial processes often remove {{d3}} as they form, which causes the equilibrium to continuously shift {{d4}}, maximising yield.

d4.tooltip: System tries to replace what was removed.

sentences.text: For the equilibrium 2SO‚ÇÇ(g) + O‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2SO‚ÇÉ(g), removing oxygen would cause the concentration of SO‚ÇÉ to {{d5}} as equilibrium shifts {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Removing reactant means less product can form.

d6.tooltip: System tries to replace the removed reactant.

sentences.text: Adding water to an aqueous equilibrium system {{d7}} all species' concentrations, which favours the reaction producing {{d8}} particles.

d8.tooltip: System opposes dilution by making more particles.

temperature_changes.title: Applying Temperature Change Principles
temperature_changes.instructions: Apply your understanding of temperature effects to predict changes in K and equilibrium position.

sentences.text: The synthesis of ammonia is exothermic: N‚ÇÇ(g) + 3H‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2NH‚ÇÉ(g), ŒîH = ‚àí92 kJ mol‚Åª¬π. At higher temperatures, K will be {{d1}} and ammonia yield will be {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Exothermic: high T favours reverse, K decreases.

d2.tooltip: Less product at equilibrium at high T.

sentences.text: A useful strategy for predicting temperature effects is to write {{d3}} as if it were a reactant or product. For exothermic reactions, heat appears on the {{d4}} side.

d3.tooltip: Treat heat like a chemical species.

d4.tooltip: Exothermic releases heat as a product.

sentences.text: The decomposition of limestone is endothermic: CaCO‚ÇÉ(s) ‚áå CaO(s) + CO‚ÇÇ(g), ŒîH = +178 kJ mol‚Åª¬π. Increasing temperature will {{d5}} the amount of CO‚ÇÇ produced and K will {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Endothermic: high T favours forward reaction.

d6.tooltip: More product at equilibrium = larger K.

sentences.text: Industrial processes using exothermic reactions face a dilemma: high temperature increases {{d7}} but decreases {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: Higher T always means faster reactions.

d8.tooltip: For exothermic: high T shifts away from products.

pressure_volume.title: Applying Pressure and Volume Principles
pressure_volume.instructions: Apply your understanding of pressure effects to predict equilibrium shifts.

sentences.text: For 2SO‚ÇÇ(g) + O‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2SO‚ÇÉ(g), there are {{d1}} moles of gas on the left and {{d2}} moles on the right.
Therefore, increasing the pressure in the SO‚ÇÇ/O‚ÇÇ/SO‚ÇÉ system will shift equilibrium to the {{d3}}, {{d4}} the yield of SO‚ÇÉ.
For the equilibrium H‚ÇÇ(g) + I‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2HI(g), changing pressure has {{d5}} effect because there are {{d6}} moles of gas on each side.

d5.tooltip: Equal moles means pressure doesn't affect position.

sentences.text: Doubling the volume of a reaction vessel is equivalent to {{d7}} the pressure, which favours the reaction producing {{d8}} moles of gas.

d7.tooltip: Volume and pressure are inversely related.

d8.tooltip: Low pressure favours more gas particles.

graphs.title: Interpreting Equilibrium Graphs
graphs.instructions: Apply your understanding to interpret and predict features of concentration-time graphs.

sentences.text: On a concentration-time graph, if reactant is suddenly added, its concentration shows a {{d1}} followed by a {{d2}} as equilibrium is re-established.

d2.tooltip: The reactant is consumed as equilibrium shifts.

sentences.text: After adding reactant, the product concentration will {{d3}} to a new level that is {{d4}} than before the disturbance.

d3.tooltip: Forward reaction makes more product over time.

d4.tooltip: Adding reactant increases product at new equilibrium.

sentences.text: When temperature is increased for an exothermic reaction, the graph would show product concentration {{d5}} and reactant concentration {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Exothermic: high T shifts left (less product).

d6.tooltip: Reverse reaction converts product back to reactants.

sentences.text: A catalyst would cause the concentration curves to reach their {{d7}} values {{d8}}, but those final values would be unchanged.

d8.tooltip: Faster reaction means equilibrium reached faster.

concentration_changes.title: Mastering Concentration Effects
concentration_changes.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by applying principles to complex scenarios and addressing common misconceptions.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that adding reactant increases K. In reality, K {{d1}} when concentration changes because K only depends on {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes K.

sentences.text: When equilibrium shifts right after adding reactant, the final reactant concentration is {{d3}} than immediately after adding, but {{d4}} than the original equilibrium.

d3.tooltip: Some reactant is consumed by the forward reaction.

d4.tooltip: System only PARTIALLY opposes - some extra remains.

sentences.text: In a closed system where CO(g) + H‚ÇÇO(g) ‚áå CO‚ÇÇ(g) + H‚ÇÇ(g), continuously removing {{d5}} would maximise the conversion of CO to {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Remove products to drive forward reaction.

d6.tooltip: CO converts to CO‚ÇÇ in the forward reaction.

sentences.text: Both adding excess reactant and removing product have the same effect of shifting equilibrium {{d7}}, but removing product is often preferred industrially because it {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: Both methods favour the forward reaction.

d8.tooltip: Removing product vs buying more reactant.

temperature_changes.title: Mastering Temperature Effects
temperature_changes.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of temperature effects on equilibrium systems.

sentences.text: For the Haber process at 450¬∞C, the rate is {{d1}} enough to be practical, but the yield is {{d2}} than at lower temperatures due to the exothermic nature of the reaction.
If K = 0.5 at 25¬∞C and K = 2.0 at 100¬∞C for a reaction, the forward reaction must be {{d3}} because K {{d4}} with increasing temperature.

d3.tooltip: K increases with T for endothermic reactions.

d4.tooltip: K went from 0.5 to 2.0 as T increased.

sentences.text: The relationship between K and temperature can be summarised: for exothermic reactions, high T means {{d5}} K and {{d6}} products; for endothermic, the opposite is true.

d5.tooltip: High T shifts exothermic reactions left.

d6.tooltip: Lower K means less product at equilibrium.

sentences.text: Cooling an exothermic reaction to increase yield creates a problem: the reaction becomes too {{d7}}. This is resolved by using a {{d8}} to maintain a reasonable rate.

d8.tooltip: Catalyst speeds up reaction without affecting equilibrium position.

pressure_volume.title: Mastering Pressure and Volume Effects
pressure_volume.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of pressure and volume effects including special cases.

sentences.text: The Contact process for sulfuric acid uses high pressure because the reaction 2SO‚ÇÇ(g) + O‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2SO‚ÇÉ(g) goes from {{d1}} moles to {{d2}} moles of gas.

d2.tooltip: Just 2 moles of SO‚ÇÉ on the right.

sentences.text: However, pressure has no effect on N‚ÇÇ(g) + O‚ÇÇ(g) ‚áå 2NO(g) because the total moles of gas is {{d3}} on both sides, meaning no {{d4}} advantage exists.

d4.tooltip: Equal moles = pressure has no effect.

sentences.text: Adding helium to a reaction vessel at constant volume increases total pressure but has {{d5}} effect on equilibrium because the {{d6}} of reacting gases are unchanged.

d5.tooltip: Inert gas doesn't change partial pressures at constant V.

d6.tooltip: Only partial pressures of reactants/products matter.

sentences.text: Compressing a gas mixture is a cost-effective way to increase yield when the product side has {{d7}} moles, unlike adding excess reactant which requires {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: High P favours the side with fewer gas moles.

graphs.title: Mastering Equilibrium Graph Analysis
graphs.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of concentration-time graph interpretation.

sentences.text: A graph showing all concentrations changing gradually to new values without any sudden jumps indicates a {{d1}} change, most likely a change in {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Temperature changes affect all species gradually.

d2.tooltip: No sudden jump = no instant addition or removal.

sentences.text: If a graph shows the same equilibrium concentrations being reached in half the time, the most likely change was the addition of a {{d3}}, which {{d4}} the equilibrium position.

d4.tooltip: Catalyst affects rate only, not position.

sentences.text: When drawing concentration-time graphs, the curves for products and reactants should {{d5}} each other because when one increases, the other must {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: If products increase, reactants decrease (and vice versa).

sentences.text: The steepness of concentration curves after a disturbance indicates reaction {{d7}}: steeper curves mean {{d8}} re-equilibration.

le_chatelier_principle.title: Le Chatelier's Principle
le_chatelier_principle.content: Le Chatelier's principle states that when an equilibrium system is disturbed by a change in conditions, the system responds by shifting to partially oppose that change and establish a new equilibrium. The key word is 'partially' - the system doesn't completely undo the change, but works against it.
keyPoints: The system PARTIALLY opposes changes, not completely
A NEW equilibrium is established, different from the original
The principle applies to changes in concentration, temperature, and pressure
The system 'fights back' against disturbances

adding_reactant.title: Effect of Adding Reactant
adding_reactant.content: When reactant is added to an equilibrium system, its concentration increases, disturbing the equilibrium. The system responds by consuming the excess reactant through the forward reaction, shifting equilibrium to the right and producing more product. The equilibrium constant K remains unchanged because it only depends on temperature.
keyPoints: Adding reactant shifts equilibrium RIGHT (toward products)
The forward reaction is favoured to use up excess reactant
K is unchanged - only position changes
Final reactant concentration is higher than original but lower than immediately after adding

adding_product.title: Effect of Adding Product
adding_product.content: When product is added to an equilibrium system, its concentration increases. The system responds by consuming the excess product through the reverse reaction, shifting equilibrium to the left and producing more reactants. Again, K remains unchanged.
keyPoints: Adding product shifts equilibrium LEFT (toward reactants)
The reverse reaction is favoured to use up excess product
K is unchanged - only position changes
Industrial processes often REMOVE product to shift equilibrium toward more product formation

temperature_exothermic.title: Temperature Effects on Exothermic Reactions
temperature_exothermic.content: For exothermic reactions (ŒîH < 0), heat can be thought of as a product. Increasing temperature adds heat to the system, which the system opposes by favouring the reverse (endothermic) reaction. This decreases product concentration at equilibrium, so K decreases. Temperature is the ONLY factor that changes K.
keyPoints: Exothermic: heat is a 'product' (A + B ‚áå C + heat)
Increasing T favours the REVERSE reaction (shifts left)
K DECREASES when T increases for exothermic reactions
High T = faster rate but lower yield for exothermic processes

temperature_endothermic.title: Temperature Effects on Endothermic Reactions
temperature_endothermic.content: For endothermic reactions (ŒîH > 0), heat can be thought of as a reactant. Increasing temperature adds heat to the system, which the system uses by favouring the forward reaction. This increases product concentration at equilibrium, so K increases.
keyPoints: Endothermic: heat is a 'reactant' (heat + A ‚áå B)
Increasing T favours the FORWARD reaction (shifts right)
K INCREASES when T increases for endothermic reactions
High T favours both rate and yield for endothermic processes

pressure_increase.title: Effect of Increasing Pressure
pressure_increase.content: When pressure is increased on a gaseous equilibrium, the system opposes by favouring the reaction that produces fewer moles of gas. This reduces the total number of gas particles and helps lower the pressure. The equilibrium constant K is unchanged because it only depends on temperature.
keyPoints: Count gas moles on each side of the equation
High pressure favours the side with FEWER gas moles
Decreasing volume has the same effect as increasing pressure
K is unchanged - only position changes

pressure_decrease.title: Effect of Decreasing Pressure
pressure_decrease.content: When pressure is decreased on a gaseous equilibrium (or volume is increased), the system opposes by favouring the reaction that produces more moles of gas. This increases the total number of gas particles and helps raise the pressure back up.
keyPoints: Low pressure favours the side with MORE gas moles
Increasing volume has the same effect as decreasing pressure
If moles are equal on both sides, pressure has no effect
K is unchanged - only position changes

inert_gas_addition.title: Effect of Adding Inert Gas
inert_gas_addition.content: Adding an inert gas (like helium or argon) at constant volume increases the total pressure but does NOT change the partial pressures of the reacting gases. Since equilibrium depends on partial pressures of reactants and products, not total pressure, equilibrium position is unchanged.
keyPoints: Inert gas at constant V: total P increases, partial P unchanged
Equilibrium position is NOT affected
K is NOT affected
This is different from compression, which DOES change partial pressures

graph_interpretation.title: Concentration-Time Graph Interpretation
graph_interpretation.content: Concentration-time graphs show how species concentrations change over time. At equilibrium, lines are horizontal (constant). When disturbed, concentrations change and then level off at new equilibrium values. Sudden jumps indicate instant changes (adding species), while gradual changes indicate temperature effects or reaction progress.
keyPoints: Horizontal lines = equilibrium (constant concentrations)
Sudden jump = instant addition or removal of species
Gradual change = temperature effect or reaction to disturbance
Products and reactants change in opposite directions (mirror curves)

catalyst_effect.title: Effect of Catalysts on Equilibrium
catalyst_effect.content: Catalysts lower the activation energy for both forward and reverse reactions equally. This speeds up the approach to equilibrium but does not change where equilibrium lies. The equilibrium position and K are completely unaffected by catalysts.
keyPoints: Catalysts speed up BOTH forward and reverse reactions equally
Equilibrium is reached FASTER but at the SAME position
K is NOT affected by catalysts
Catalysts affect kinetics (rate), not thermodynamics (position)
